description.other_details:
Teasdale G, Jennett B. Assessment of coma and impaired consciousness. A practical scale. Lancet 1974,2:81-84.
Teasdale GM, Murray L. Revisiting the Glasgow Coma Scale and Coma Score. Intensive Care Medicine. 2000; 26: 153-154.
Worrall K. Use of the Glasgow coma scale in infants. Paediatric nursing 2004;16(4):45-50.
Tatman A, Warren A, Williams A, Powell JE, Whitehouse W. Development of a modified paediatric coma scale in intensive care clinical practice. Archives of disease in childhood 1997;77(6):519.

details.purpose:
Za opazovanje odzivnosti pacienta pri ocenjevanju zavesti le tega.
Lestvica je znana tudi kot JGCS (James GCS)
details.use: Se uporablja v situacijah, ko je potrebno oceniti zavest pacienta. Lestvica je prilagojena oceni zavesti pri otrocih in tudi tistih otrocih, ki so mlajši od 2 let. Opazujejo se tri področja: govr, gibanje in premikanje oči. Rezultat je seštevek vseh faktorjev iz vseh treh področij opazovanja odzivnosti in njihov rezultat
details.misuse: Se ne uporablja za oceno zavesti odraslih. V ta namen se uporablja OBSERVATION.glasgow_coma.v1.adl.

details.purpose:
To record clinical observations regarding responsiveness of a subject to stimuli as an objective assessment of the conscious state of a child subject.
Also known as JGCS (James' GCS).
details.use: Use in any clinical situation to assess the level of consciousness of a subject, with the exception of infants and young children. The three response values are considered separately as well as their sum. The minimum possible Total score value is 3 and the maximum possible is 15. The Total score can be derived as the sum of the recorded scores for each of the eye, motor and verbal responses. The EMV score can be derived as a composite from each of the recorded response scores, for example E3 M2 V4 represents the conscious state of a subject who opens eyes to speech, has an extensor response to pain and utters incomprehensible sounds. If any one of the eye, motor or verbal responses cannot be assessed - for example if the subject is intubated and not able to respond verbally, or paralysed and not able to provide a motor response - the score recorded for the response is 1 and a modifier attached. If the subject is intubated the verbal response component can be represented as V1t, where t = tube, or V1Intubated. If the subject has severe facial/eye swelling or injuries and can't open their eyes, the eye response component can be represented as E1c, where c=closed. Often the numeric one is omitted, so the eye response component can be expressed more simply as Ec, for example Ec M2 V4. Clinical Decision support should be based upon each of the specific records of eye, motor and verbal responses and the explicit statements that a response cannot be assessed, rather than the derived and composite EMV score.
details.misuse: Not to be used for assessing adults- use the OBSERVATION.glasgow_coma.v1.adl to ensure that the eye, motor and verbal response choices are appropriate.

items.items: Best motor response to stumulus in infant less than 2 years old.
Withdraws in response to painful stimulus.
Best verbal response to stimulus in a child older than 2 years.
Best verbal response to stimulus in a infant younger than 2 years.
Moans or groans, but no recognisable words.
Converses, but confused and disoriented in their environment.
Less than usual ability or spontaneous irritable cry.
The infant is alert babbles, coos or says words or sentences to their usual ability.
Best grimace response in response to pain. May be used instead of verbal response for intubated patients.
Mild grimace or some change in facial expression to pain.
Less than usual spontaneous ability or only responds to touch.
Fifteen point scale used to assess the level of consciousness of a subject. Also known as the Modified Glasgow Coma Scale.
Fifteen point scale used to assess the level of consciousness of a child subject. Also known as the Modified Glasgow Coma Scale for Infants and Children.
Best verbal response to stimulus in an adult.
Best motor response to stimulus in child over 2 years old.
Eyes open in response to pain
Opens eyes in response to painful stimuli in limbs.
Eyes open in response to speech
Opens eyes in response to any verbal approach.
Moans or groans, but no recognisable words.
Intelligible speech, but no conversational exchange.
Converses, but confused and disoriented in their environment.
Localised movement in response to pain.
The sum of the 3 ordinal scores for each component parameter.
Eye Motor Verbal profile expressing each component individually. This can be derived as a combination of the preceding elements.
Not able to test eye response
Not possible to test eye responses - for example in the case of associated severe facial/eye swelling or damage.
Not able to test verbal response
Not possible to test verbal responses - for example in the case of associated intubation.
Not able to test motor response
Not possible to test motor responses - for example in the case of associated limb paralysis.
Comment about measurement of the Scale, especially if it was not possible to assess a response.
Reason for inability to test eye response
Reason for inability to test eye response.
Reason for inability to test verbal response
Reason for inability to test verbal response.
Reason for inability to test motor response
Reason for inability to test motor response.

Opazovanje govora pri otrocih mlajših od 30 let
Dojenček je živahen in poskuša komunicirati
Se ne odziva na bolečino s spakovanjem obraza

Lestvica za oceno zavesti v pediatriji

Odpira oči kot odgovor na nagovarjanje
Seštevek 3 ocen za vsako komponento ocenjevanja
Eye Motor Verbal profil, ki ocenjuje vasko komponento posebej
